docs.lead_paragraph: WITH soaring unemployment, swooning consumer confidence and an economy skirting its second recession in two years, Germany seems to be the undisputed holder of the title ''sick man of Europe.'' What the country needs, most economists and business leaders say, is a bracing dose of the type of free-market medicine prescribed for Britain by Margaret Thatcher in the 1980's, when that country held the ''sick man'' title.

headline.main: On a Sickbed, Is Germany Too Weak For a Cure?

docs.abstract: Mark Landler column on debate over whether current troubles of German economy argue for or against a drive to undo country's deep-rooted maladies: calcified labor market, subsidies that make unemployment almost as lucrative as working and bloated health care system; some economists say forcing through painful changes now could further depress Germany's consumers, deepening its malaise and hurting European neighbors; others say that government should use bad economic news as pretext for reform and that resulting resurgence in confidence in corporate sector will offset slide on consumer side; photo of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder (M)
docs.snippet: WITH soaring unemployment, swooning consumer confidence and an economy skirting its second recession in two years, Germany seems to be the undisputed holder of the title ''sick man of Europe.''    What the country needs, most economists and business...

docs.lead_paragraph: NELLA BRAIOTTA was 35 years old when she decided to come clean. She had a job as a nursery school aide and was narrating a picture book to a little boy when it happened. The child looked at her accusingly. ''That's not the way the story goes,'' he said. ''You're reading it wrong.'' All through her own childhood Ms. Braiotta had faked, pantomiming her way through life, pretending she could understand the words on job applications, medication bottles and on the pages of her beloved Bible. She graduated from high school, but she did not even know what a vowel was.

headline.main: When Mommy Or Daddy Can't Read

docs.abstract: Article on illiteracy in Westchester County, NY, and programs that help adults learn to read; vast majority of those seeking help at Literacy Volunteers in Elmsford are immigrants, many of whom can barely read or write in their native languages, but about 20 percent of clients are American-born; Nella Braiotta, 50, her tutor, Paula Cancro and other students and tutors comment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. Howard J. Winter, in his letter of March 2, tried to gain our sympathy for the doctors' cause by informing us that his income is $250,000 and his malpractice insurance is $100,000.
docs.abstract: Ellen Platz letter on Dr Howard J Winter's March 2 letter holds malpractice insurance is business expense; says what matters is what percentage insurance is of his total revenue, not his income
docs.snippet: To the Editor:   Dr. Howard J. Winter, in his letter of March 2, tried to gain our sympathy for the doctors' cause by informing us that his income is $250,000 and his malpractice insurance is $100,000.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Associated Press reported late last month that the Bush administration was ''stunned'' by sharp criticism of its original plan to provide prescription drug benefits for Medicare recipients only if they enroll in private health maintenance organizations. So the plan was altered last week to offer limited drug benefits to those enrolled in traditional fee-for-service Medicare, though H.M.O. members would still receive much more extensive coverage. But that modification, still part of a broader effort to recast Medicare so that its members have strong incentives to join managed-care plans, was derided by Democrats on Capitol Hill and received a lukewarm reception at best from Republicans.

headline.main: Misgivings About Nudging the Elderly Into Managed Care

docs.abstract: Fred Brock 'Seniority' column criticizes Bush administration's effort to force Medicare patients into managed care by means of prescription drug benefit; cites public's unhappiness with HMO runaround and restrictions, scarcity of HMO's in many rural areas and more general concern about returning medical care of older Americans to private market; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE Associated Press reported late last month that the Bush administration was ''stunned'' by sharp criticism of its original plan to provide prescription drug benefits for Medicare recipients only if they enroll in private health maintenance...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE amendments to the current state budget that Gov. John Rowland signed into law last month will affect virtually all residents, but as with all such money-saving and tax maneuvers, some will feel the changes to a greater degree than others. The revised budget raised income taxes, business taxes, taxes for cigarette smokers, and for most health clubs. But the hardest hit may well be the working poor, some of whom lost their eligibility for everything from state-subsidized day care to health-insurance. And in the 2003-2004 budget the governor announced last week, more cuts and tax increases look to be on the way.

headline.main: A Budget Fix That Touches Everyone

docs.abstract: Article assesses impact that amendments to current Connecticut state budget will likely have on residents; revised budget, which further cuts social service programs, will hit working poor the hardest; some residents will lose eligibility for state-subsidized day care and health insurance; taxes on income, businesses, cigarettes and most health clubs will also be raised; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF the rules were changed to favor David F. D'Alessandro, the next Winter Games would include a biathlon of business and marksmanship. That is how precisely the chief executive of John Hancock Financial Services has taken aim against the United States Olympic Committee in recent months. Mr. D'Alessandro has long been an outspoken critic of the International Olympic Committee, as in 1999 when he fought to clean up the I.O.C. after the Salt Lake City bribery scandal.
docs.abstract: Profile of John Hancock Financial Services chief executive David F D'Alessandro in light of his pressure on United States Olympic Committee to disclose how much of its budget actually goes to athletes or risk losing $50 million of Hancock sponsorhip for each four-year Olympic cycle; he comments, interview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Sidney M. Wolfe (''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' Op-Ed, March 4) distorts the malpractice crisis, which he attributes to an epidemic of medical errors.

headline.main: Are Doctors or Lawsuits at Fault?

docs.abstract: Dr Richard Eisner letter holds Sidney M Wolfe's Mar 4 article errs in linking malpractice crisis to epidemic of medical errors; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Sidney M. Wolfe (''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' Op-Ed, March 4) distorts the malpractice crisis, which he attributes to an epidemic of medical errors.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' by Sidney M. Wolfe (Op-Ed, March 4): All of us in the practice of medicine, like our patients, must pay for the malpractice of a relative few.

headline.main: Are Doctors or Lawsuits at Fault?

docs.abstract: Dr Paul Bloustein letter on Sidney M Wolfe's Mar 4 article opposes his call for public access to national practioner data bank, noting even careful, competent doctors are sued and sometimes settle cases; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' by Sidney M. Wolfe (Op-Ed, March 4):     All of us in the practice of medicine, like our patients, must pay for the malpractice of a relative few.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' by Sidney M. Wolfe (Op-Ed, March 4): The silence of doctors protecting their own is deafening. Doctors want to be paid well but don't want to be held accountable.

headline.main: Are Doctors or Lawsuits at Fault?

docs.abstract: Bruce Martin letter on Sidney M Wolfe's Mar 4 article holds patients should have access to data on errors made by doctors; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' by Sidney M. Wolfe (Op-Ed, March 4):     The silence of doctors protecting their own is deafening. Doctors want to be paid well but don't want to be held accountable.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' by Sidney M. Wolfe (Op-Ed, March 4): There is no question that state medical boards should discipline doctors who are incompetent, careless or for other reasons do not provide acceptable care. But in focusing on malpractice suits, Dr. Wolfe is looking in the wrong direction.

headline.main: Are Doctors or Lawsuits at Fault?
